column1: Hormones like testosterone and estradiol can attach to your brain cells. A brain cell looks different from cells in other parts of the body: it has a cell body
column2: but also has parts that look like wires sticking out. A brain cell often has many shorter "wires
column3: called dendrites for receiving signals from other cells. These cells also have one longer wire" called an axon
column4: which sends signals to other cells.There are two main ways that hormones can influence your brain cells.First
column5: hormones can influence how the brain is organized
column6: and these are changes that take some time to occur. Changes in brain organization can include changes in the number of cells
column7: or changes in the size and shape of dendrites or axons. Testosterone
column9: influences the development of new cells in a brain region called the medial amygdala. Because boys make more testosterone during puberty
column10: this region becomes bigger in boys than girls. This was found in animal research
column11: but studies on humans that looked at hormone levels and the size of the amygdala suggest it works the same in humans.
